article_title: Q&A: Memorial Hermann dives deeper into insurance business
article_text:
Q&A: Memorial Hermann dives deeper into insurance business

Memorial Hermann Health System has hired Daniel Styf as its new...

As the old model of health care coverage continues to give way in this country, hospitals increasingly are getting into the insurance business - cutting out what they see as the middleman of traditional carriers.

article_metadata.description: Memorial Hermann moves deeper into health coverage  Houston's Memorial Hermann Health System is on the forefront of the trend and continues to move deeper into this new hybrid of coverage and care.  Dan Styf, newly arrived from Atlanta where he helped shepherd a similar type of joint venture, has come to Houston to take the reins as senior vice president and CEO of Memorial Hermann Health Plans.  Memorial Hermann Health System is a 13-, soon to be 15-hospital system, 4,000 affiliated physicians from every "-ology" you can imagine.  [...] we have the health system, and now we have our health plan.  The reason we put coverage and care together is it allows us to proactively invest in the health of our community and patients.  [...] doctors and hospitals work best when they're 100 percent focused on taking care of patients, not on silly insurance company rules.  How is this different from a Kaiser Permanente system, the nation's largest managed care system that also offers its own health plan?  [...] if you're still seeing patients with other insurance coverage, don't you still have those fights?  Medicare Advantage now allows private health plans to enter that market.  [...] the individual market is more real, so that employers are more frequently not offering coverage, allowing their employees to go to the individual market.  What Medicare Advantage does is, the federal government says instead of spending all the money on a traditional Medicare program, we're going to allow you, Memorial Hermann, to come in and we're going to pay you for that patient for the year and let you offer benefits and offer coverage and care for that patient.  If you look around the country at these health systems that are entering the coverage space, Medicare Advantage is the primary vehicle.  Nationally, almost every significant health system of the scope and scale of Memorial Hermann is at least looking at this type of opportunity.  [...] the health plan in Atlanta you were involved with that was offered by two nonprofit hospitals failed.  In Memorial Hermann, we have a single health system operating a single health plan.
article_metadata.author.name: By Jenny Deam
